nodes.text: If only widespread gun ownership was 'safe'...
And I see you refuse to address my point. This argument might have some relevance and validity if you would back it up.
What if you kill them before they kill you? Good luck arguing to that one!

So I have the choice between staying safe and then claiming insurance damages, or risking my life to kill a burglar and (likely) cause damage to my own property in the process? Somehow, I'd rather stay safe. Better to lose my laptop than my life.
And how many people per capita own guns in each of the areas in your table?
Actually, try comparing murder rates with those of the UK - was my point, especially murder by gun. You've got your table of state shootings, and I've already argued against it.

A third of the nation is armed, many with weapons more powerful than the standard issue arms of the military. If we get p!$$ed off bad enough, it's gonna get very ugly. The military doesn't have the manpower to stop 100 million outraged and armed individuals.

And who is going to lead them? How will they remain safe? This isn't a game of Warcraft, where the 'player' can control all individuals at the touch of a button. An organised few can defeat a disorganised many, and often do.
That's what the world thought about Camp Delta, and the CIA prisons, and the invasion of Iraq. Since when has the Us given a damn about the views of otherplacians?
I think a more sensible question would be 'How is this relevant?'.
